data.title: Chicago 7 trial and related music and recordings
data.meta_description: Posts about Chicago 7 trial and related music and recordings written by craigr244
data.text:
The Chicago Seven/Eight

I just finished reading the book “From the Trial of the Chicago 8/7 – The Tales of Hoffman” – edited from the official trial transcripts.

Like many, I recall the drama that unfolded on the national TV news network broadcasts back in March of 1968 during the Democrat National Convention, held in Chicago. I remember the outrage I felt witnessing the assaults out on the streets while the convention continued on the floor of the International Amphitheater.

More than a few convention attendees pleaded for the police action to cease, a plea that fell on deaf ears.

But what I really never had a understanding of was what was to transpire inside the court room in Chicago beginning. The book is a chronological listing of selected dialogue exchanges taking place during the trial.

That is about all I have to relate about that time in our country’s history. Like most everything I present here, I turn to the vinyl side of things, recordings about those times, recordings by folks who factored into the story – not necessarily recordings about the story.

There was plenty of material to draw from due to the celebrity roster that he defense paraded (or attempted to parade) through the courtroom.

If you are curious, I recommend reading the book especially after all this time has passed. At times it is uplifting, at times sad, and at time disappointing on the part of both sides – including the prosecution team, the defense team, the presiding judge and the defendants. Sort of like a room full of little children at times. But those were very different times….

PS: The trial resulted in many, many contempt citations as well as guilty verdicts, but over the next few following years, many charges were dropped, and many/most sentences were overturned, or imprisonments not fully enforced. Also, judge Hoffman was officially censored for some of his behavior on the bench.

The Motion Picture

With all of this, I just finished viewing the motion picture “The Trial of the Chicago 7”. I feel that it was very well done, quality actors, started off in what appeared to be an accurate historical account but then, just past the middle going into the end, Hollywood took over.

Best thing to do is read the trial account above then watch and decide for yourself.

Chicago Seven/Eight Selected Related Discography

Timothy Leary

Country Joe McDonald

William S. Burroughs (Witness for the Defense)

Burroughs LP – “Dead City Radio” – 1990

Noam Chomsky (Witness for the Defense

Judy Collins (Witness for the Defense)

Witness Judy Collins from Denver, Colorado had the intention of singing “Where Have All the Flowers Gone” in court but was prevented doing so by Judge Hoffman and so she read the lyrics.

Walter Cronkite

Various Artists LP – with Walter Cronkite on “The Campaign Part III and Chicago Convention” – 1968

Cronkite LP Box Set “I Can Hear It Now the Sixties” with Republican and Democratic Convention 1968″ – 1970

Cronkite LP Box Set “The Way it Was the Sixties” with “Republican and Democratic Convention 1968” – 1983 (reissue)

The Doors

Doors song “Peace Frog” from the LP “Morrison Hotel” released with lyrics “Blood in the streets/ in the town of Chicago”

Warren Farren – Song “Chicago 7”

Allen Ginsberg (Witness for the Defense)

Ginsberg attempted to demonstrate his mantra of “ooohm” but was cut short by an objection by the prosecution and judge Hoffman

Dick Gregory – Witness for the Defense

Gregory 45 EP – with “Black Rioters” – 1969

Gregory LP – “Gregory On” – 1969

Gregory 45 LP – with “Chicago, My Home Town” – 1973

Gregory LP – “The Light Side: The Dark Side – with “Black Rioters”

Arlo Guthrie (Witness for the Defense)

Charley Haden

Charlie Haden & the Liberation Music Orchestra with “Circus ’68 ’69”

Jim Hartley & the Orange State Playboys

Jim Hartley 45 – “Telling it Straight in ’68”

Tom Hayden – Defendant

Hayden Tape – “Rolling Stone Tom Hayden Interview”

Abbie Hoffman – Defendant

Abbie Hoffman LP – “Wake Up! America!” – 1971

Rev. Jesse Jackson (Witness for the Defense)

Jesse Jackson LP – “I Am Somebody (Know Your Enemy)” – 1971

Jesse Jackson LP – “Our Time Has Come” – 1974

Charles Kuralt

Kuralt LP – “The Incredible Year: 1968” with “The Conventions; The Campaign, Protest & War” – 1968

The Lumpen – Song “Free Bobby Now” b/w “No More” – 1970

Black Panther group

Macabre

Macabre LP CD “Dahmer” with “Coming to Chicago” – 2000

Malcolm X

Malcolm X CD LP Track from “A Passel of Pomp & A Circus of Circumstance: Historic Convention Coverage from the Pacifica Radio Archives” with “The 1968 National Democratic Convention” – 2004

Grocho Marx (Intended Witness for the Defense)

Was invited to appear by Weiner – Was “honored” but declined feeling he would offend the court

Country Joe McDonald (Witness for the Defense)

Country Joe Single “I-Feel-Like-I’m-Fixin’-To-Die” – October 1970

Country Joe LP “Hold On It’s Coming” with “Mr. Big’s Pig” – May 1971

Country Joe LP “War War War” – July 1971

Memphis Slim

Memphis Slim Song – “Chicago Seven” – June 1971

Michigan Stone Foxx

MSF 45 – “Love Not War” – August 1968

Mushroom

LP – “Americans Own the Moon, They Bought It from the Germans – Who Won It During a Poker Game in World War Two (1968 Chicago Democratic Convention Remix)” – 2000

Graham Nash

Graham Nash Song – “Chicago” from LP “Songs for Beginners” – May 1971

As a tribute to defendant Bobby Seale, the song contained the lyrics:

“So your brother’s bound and gagged, and they’ve chained him to a chair… Won’t you please come to Chicago, Just to sing.”

Scoop Nisker

Scoop LP Tape Cut from “Radio Archival Oddities” with “The 1968 National Democrat Convention” – 1968

Laura Nyro

Laura Nyro song “Christmas in My Soul” on LP “Christmas and the Beads of Sweat” – 1970

Phil Ochs (Defense Witness)

At the trial, witness Phil Ochs intended to perform the song “I Ain’t Marchin’ Anymore” at the trial upon being called to the stand. Judge Hoffman prevented him from doing so.

Phil Ochs LP – “Rehearsals for Retirement” – April 1969

Note the grave marker inscription. The song “William Butler Yeats Visits Lincoln Park” describes the events on the street of Chicago during the protests.

Phil Ochs LP – “I Ain’t Marching Anymore” – February 1965

David Peel & the Lower East Side

Davd Peel LP “The Pope Smokes Dope” with “The Chicago Conspiracy” 1972

Jerry Rubin (Defendant)

Rubin LP Track from John Lennon LP “The Lost Lennon Tapes” with “Rubin on Mike Douglas; The F.B.I.; The First Deportation Order”

The Who

Who LP – “Woodstock ’69’ with “The Abbie Hoffman Incident” – 2014

Post Script:

The Life and Times of the Eight

Rennie Davis

Served in D.C. as chief of staff for the “Council of Economic Advisers” – Member of “Students for a Democratic Society” (SDS) – Member of “the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam” – Received a concussion from police beating in the Chicago Democrat Convention demonstrations – Joined the “Divine Light Mission under Gura Maharaj Ji in the 1970s – Started the “Foundation for a New Humanity” – Advised Fortune 500 Companies

Died on February 2nd, 2021 at his home in Berthoud, Colorado at the age of 80

David Dellinger

Left college during the Depression to live among unemployed hobos – Fought against the Nationalist faction led by Francisco Franco in Spain – Imprisoned during WWII as a conscientious objector – A member of the Socialist Party of America and the Young People’s Socialist League – Co-founder of the Central Committe for Conscientious Objectors – Help lead the Freedom Marches in the deep South – Sponsored the “War Tax Resistance Project – Founder for “Seven Days” magazine in 1975, a far left publication

Died on May 25th, 2004 at the age of 88

John Froines

Was the director of “Toxic Substances” group of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OHSA) – Graduated from the University of Berkeley in 1963 – Member or Students for a Democratic Society (SDS) while attending Yale University – Recognized by the “Physicians for Social Responsibility” in Los Angeles

Died on July 13th, 2022

Tom Hayden

Attended Catholic church led by antisemite priest Charles Coughlin – Hayden broke away from the Church as a result as a teen – Became a member of the “Students for a Democratic Society” (SDS) and was severely beaten while participating in the Freedom Rides – Composed the “SDS Manifesto” from a prison cell in Albany, Georgia – Served as President of SDS in 1962 and 1963 – Visited North Vietnam in 1965 – Joined the “National Mobilization Committe to End the Ward in Vietnam” – Founded the “Indochina Peace Campaign” (IPC) in 1972 – Created the “Campaign for Economic Democracy” with his wife Jane Fonda – Member of California State Senate 1992-2000

Died on October 23rd, 2016 at the age of 76

Abie Hoffman

Was expelled from high school before graduating. He had declared himself an atheist, composing a paper on the subject which led to a fight with a teacher and the expulsion – Co-founded the “Youth International Party” (YIP) with Jerry Rubin – Was a member of the “Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committe” (SNCC) – Was associated with the “Diggers” in California but fell out of favor with the group after publishing a book about them – Staged a demonstration at the New York Stock Exchange dropping dollar bills into the exchange from a balcony – Interrupted a performance by Britain’s “Who” at Woodstock in 1969 to protest the jailing of White Panther Party member John Sinclair – Was charged with drug distribution (cocaine) in 1973 – Led protests against the CIA in the 1980s and was arrested – Had an FBI file of over 13,000 pages

Died on April 12th, 1989 at the age of 52 taking his own life

Jerry Rubin

Co-founder of the Youth International Party (YIP/”Yippies”) – Organizer of the Vietnam Day Committee – Appeared before HUAC dressed once as Santa Claus and once dressed in Viet Cong style pajamas – Nominated a pig named “Pigasus” as a U.S. Presidential candidate – Co-organizer of the “March on the Pentagon” in 1967 – Joined with Allen Ginsberg in attempting to levitate the Pentagon by leading a crowd in chants – Departed his life of activism and became and entrepreneur and businessman and an early investor in Apple Computer, resulting in becoming a multi-millionaire.

Died on November 28th, 1994 at the age of 56 a victim from being struck by a vehicle when while crossing the street

Bobby Seale

Enlisted in the United States Air Force in 1955 – Member of the “Afro-American Association” in 1962 – Worked in the “North Oakland Neighborhood Anti-Poverty Center – Co-founder of the “Black Panther Party” in 1966 along with Huey Newton – Unsuccessfully ran for office of Mayor of Oakland in 1973

Lee Weiner

Studied at Hebrew University of Jerusalem – Attended Loyola University in Chicago obtaining a master’s degree in Social Work – Was a marshal with the “National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam” – Was much more low key than other Chicago 7/8 Defendants not seeking the limelight – Fired from staff of Rutgers in 1972 due to joking about starting a ‘new communist party’ at a Black Panther get together which ended up in print – Worked for the “Anti-Defamation League” – Vice President of “Americares Foundation”
